Okay, all I can google or found on wiki regarding the traction slider is "To increase traction, add more weight." In short, I do not have an answer for that.

Since I have 15 km to go on the worst Rover wheel, I kinda want an answer as to what does that tweakable do. Don't exactly want to fly off another Mun crater and get Valentina killed again.

And yes, next time I will pack an RCS flyer instead. Or design something that will fit either a Mk-II cargobay or Service Bay 2.5m

Putting the slider to 0 basically means that wheel is on ice.

Putting it at 5 makes it so that it is guaranteed impossible for the wheel to move sideways, ever. It also doubles the amount of energy it takes to make the wheel roll forwards. (OK, maybe it's not double, but it's more.) It also makes the brakes work better -- because when you lock up the brakes, you stop. Even on 50 degree slopes.

Leaving it at less than 5 makes it so that when you hit a pothole, or jump the rover over a cliff, your rover spins out instead of flipping when it lands.

The automatic traction control applies the brakes when it detects that a wheel has started sliding. And wheels slide a lot. Especially on hills. So every time you want to go up a hill, turn it off or you will be fighting your own brakes as you climb the hill.
Thanks. I will try to adjust the slider. Now I am returning with Jeb. Hope he won't get killed.
